# Contributing to CurriculumGen-Technical-Syllabus-Generator-CLI-Tool

Thank you for considering contributing to the CurriculumGen project! We welcome contributions that enhance the tool's functionality, improve its performance, or extend its educational capabilities.

## 1. Our Guiding Principles

This project adheres to the **Apex Technical Authority** standards, emphasizing:

*   **Zero-Defect:** Aim for high-quality, well-tested code.
*   **High-Velocity:** Streamline the contribution process for rapid iteration.
*   **Future-Proof:** Build with maintainability and scalability in mind.
*   **Professionalism:** Maintain a high standard in all aspects of development and documentation.

## 2. Code of Conduct

This project adheres to the Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct. Please read the full text [here](https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/0/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.html) to understand the expectations for participation.

## 3. How to Contribute

We accept contributions in the form of bug reports, feature requests, documentation improvements, and code contributions.

### 3.1. Reporting Bugs

If you find a bug, please check if it has already been reported. If not, open a new [issue](https://github.com/chirag127/CurriculumGen-Technical-Syllabus-Generator-CLI-Tool/issues).

When reporting a bug, please include:

*   A clear, descriptive title.
*   The steps to reproduce the bug.
*   The expected behavior and the actual behavior.
*   Your operating system and the tool's version (if applicable).
*   Any relevant error messages or console output.

### 3.2. Suggesting Enhancements or Features

We are always looking for ideas to improve CurriculumGen. If you have a suggestion for a new feature or an enhancement to an existing one, please open a new [issue](https://github.com/chirag127/CurriculumGen-Technical-Syllabus-Generator-CLI-Tool/issues).

### 3.3. Contributing Code

We use a standard GitHub workflow for code contributions:

1.  **Fork the Repository:** Create your own fork of `chirag127/CurriculumGen-Technical-Syllabus-Generator-CLI-Tool`.
2.  **Clone Your Fork:** `git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/CurriculumGen-Technical-Syllabus-Generator-CLI-Tool`
3.  **Set Up Development Environment:** Follow the setup instructions in the `README.md`.
4.  **Create a New Branch:** `git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name` or `git checkout -b bugfix/your-bug-fix`.
5.  **Make Your Changes:** Write your code, ensuring it adheres to project standards and includes appropriate tests.
6.  **Test Your Changes:** Run all tests (`pytest` is recommended for Python projects) to ensure your changes haven't introduced regressions.
7.  **Lint and Format:** Ensure your code passes linting and formatting checks using Ruff (`ruff check --fix` and `ruff format`).
8.  **Commit Your Changes:** `git commit -m "feat: Add new syllabus generation capability"` or `git commit -m "fix: Resolve syllabus parsing error"`.
9.  **Push to Your Fork:** `git push origin feature/your-feature-name`.
10. **Open a Pull Request:** Submit a pull request from your fork to the `main` branch of `chirag127/CurriculumGen-Technical-Syllabus-Generator-CLI-Tool`.

### 3.4. Code Style and Standards

*   **Language:** This project is written in **Python**.
*   **Package Management:** We use **uv** for managing dependencies.
*   **Linting & Formatting:** **Ruff** is used for code quality checks and formatting. Ensure your code passes Ruff checks before submitting.
*   **Testing:** **Pytest** is used for unit and integration testing. All new code should be accompanied by relevant tests.
*   **Architecture:** The project follows a **Modular Monolith** pattern.
